bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, August 7, 1951

div1.p: Tate thanks Hench for his citation of Kelly's Reed biography. Tate criticizes the accuracy of Kelly's account of the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, August 7, 1951
div1.opener:
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley 3 California
August 7, 1951
P.S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you kindly for your thought-
fulness in sending me the excerpt from catalog citing
the book, “Walter Reed,” by Doctor Kelly.

It is an excellent book so far as
the life of Major Walter Reed is concerned, and I en-
joyed reading it some years ago. But some of the part
referring to the Yellow Fever Experiment, resting so
much on the testimony of Lena Warner, that it was, I'll
be charitable enough enough to say, erroneous, that I
had no further interest in it.

The only book I was anxious to get
was General Truby's story, and finally through his effort
,Major General Armstrong, now The Surgeon General, sent
me a copy from Army stock with compliments of the Medical
Department.

But I do thank you so much for think-
ing of me, and hope you will remember me with any further
copies of talks you, yourself, may make on this, or any
other subject, for I find your method of expression ever
realistic and enthralling.

As I am writing this, please permit
a little man to join the great in congratulating you on
the well-deserved honors you have received.
